recipes.recipe_description: Pork Sinigang is a classic Filipino sour soup made with pork, vegetables, and tamarind broth. It's a comfort food that's perfect for cold or rainy days.
recipes.recipe_instructions:
1. In a large pot, bring water and pork to a boil. Skim off any foam.
2. Add onions and tomatoes. Simmer for 30 minutes.
3. Add long green beans and eggplant. Cook for 10 minutes.
4. Add tamarind soup base and spinach. Stir well.
5. Simmer for 5 minutes.
6. Serve hot with rice.

recipes.recipe_description: Pork Sinigang is a classic Filipino sour soup made with pork, vegetables, and tamarind broth. It's a comfort food that's perfect for cold or rainy days.
recipes.recipe_instructions:
1. In a large pot, bring water and pork to a boil. Skim off any foam.
2. Add onions and tomatoes. Simmer for 30 minutes.
3. Add long green beans and eggplant. Cook for 10 minutes.
4. Add tamarind soup base and spinach. Stir well.
5. Simmer for 5 minutes.
6. Serve hot with rice.

recipes.recipe_description: Pork Adobo is a popular Filipino dish that features tender chunks of pork braised in a savory sauce of vinegar, soy sauce, and spices. It's a flavorful and comforting meal that's perfect with a side of rice.
recipes.recipe_instructions:
1. In a large pot or Dutch oven, combine pork, garlic, soy sauce, vinegar, water, bay leaves, and black peppercorns. Stir well.
2. Bring to a boil over medium-high heat.
3. Lower the heat to medium-low and let simmer for 45-60 minutes or until the pork is tender.
4. Add brown sugar and stir well.
5. Simmer for another 10-15 minutes.
6. Serve hot with rice.

recipes.recipe_description: Pinakbet is a classic Filipino dish that features mixed vegetables simmered in a savory sauce of fish sauce, garlic, onions, and tomatoes. It's a healthy and flavorful way to enjoy a variety of vegetables.
recipes.recipe_instructions:
1. Heat a large pot over medium heat. Add pork belly and cook until browned.
2. Add garlic, onions, and tomatoes. Cook until softened.
3. Add water and fish sauce. Bring to a boil.
4. Add bitter melon, eggplant, and okra. Stir well.
5. Reduce heat to low and let simmer for 10-15 minutes or until the vegetables are tender.
6. Serve hot with rice.

recipes.recipe_description: Tinola is a classic Filipino soup dish made with chicken cooked in a ginger broth with vegetables. It's a comforting and nourishing dish that's perfect for chilly days or when you're feeling under the weather.
recipes.recipe_instructions:
1. In a large pot, saut√© ginger, garlic, and onions over medium heat until fragrant.
2. Add chicken and cook until lightly browned.
3. Add fish sauce and water. Bring to a boil.
4. Add chayote and simmer for 15 minutes or until the chicken is cooked through and the chayote is tender.
5. Add malunggay leaves and cook for an additional 2 minutes or until wilted.
6. Serve hot with rice.

recipes.recipe_description: A classic Filipino comfort food made with mung beans, pork, and vegetables
recipes.recipe_instructions:
1. Wash the mung beans thoroughly. In a pot, boil the beans in 4 cups of water until soft. Remove from heat and set aside. 

2. In a separate pan, saut√© the onion and garlic until fragrant. Add the pork and cook until brown. Add the tomato and cook until soft. 

3. Pour in the boiled mung beans, including the water used to cook them. Add more water if necessary. Bring to a boil and let it simmer for 10-15 minutes or until the pork is tender. 

4. Add the fish sauce and spinach leaves. Cook for 2-3 minutes. 

5. Serve hot with rice. Enjoy!

recipes.recipe_description: A simple and healthy dish made with fresh fish that's perfect for summer grilling.
recipes.recipe_instructions: 1. Preheat grill to high heat. 2. Clean and pat dry the fish. 3. Season both sides of the fish with salt and pepper. 4. Drizzle olive oil over the fish. 5. Place the fish on the grill and cook for about 6-8 minutes on each side, until fully cooked. 6. Squeeze lemon juice over the fish before serving. 7. Serve hot and enjoy!

1. In a large mixing bowl, combine soy sauce, vinegar, lemon or calamansi juice, garlic, onion, salt, and ground black pepper. Stir until well combined.

2. Add the pork belly to the marinade mixture. Massage the meat to fully absorb the marinade. Cover the bowl with cling wrap and marinate in the fridge for at least 3 hours, or overnight for best results.

3. Preheat your grill to medium-high heat.

4. Remove the marinated pork belly from the fridge and let it sit at room temperature for 20-30 minutes.

5. Grill the pork belly on each side for 8-10 minutes or until cooked through. While grilling, baste the meat with the remaining marinade. Add the banana ketchup and sprite or 7-up on the last 5 minutes of grilling. This will give the meat a sweet and savory flavor and will also make it juicy and tender.

6. Remove from the grill and let it rest for a few minutes before slicing. Serve with your favorite dipping sauce and enjoy!

recipes.recipe_description: Bulalo is a popular Filipino soup dish made with beef shanks and marrow bones.
recipes.recipe_instructions:
1. Boil the beef shanks and marrow bones in a large pot of water for 5 minutes, then discard the water and rinse the bones.
2. Return the bones to the pot and add 12 cups of water. Bring to a boil and skim off any impurities that rise to the surface.
3. Add the onion, garlic, and peppercorns to the pot. Lower the heat to a simmer and cook for 2 hours, or until the meat is tender.
4. Add the corn and bok choy to the pot and continue cooking for another 15 minutes, or until the vegetables are tender.
5. Season with salt to taste. Serve hot.

recipes.recipe_description: A Filipino dish made of thinly sliced beef marinated in a mixture of calamansi juice, soy sauce, and onions.
recipes.recipe_instructions:
1. Marinate the beef in calamansi juice, soy sauce, and onions for at least 30 minutes.
2. Heat oil in a pan and saut√© garlic until golden brown.
3. Add the marinated beef and cook until brown.
4. Pour in the water and simmer for 10 minutes or until the beef is tender.
5. Serve hot with steamed rice.

recipes.recipe_description: Kare-Kare is a classic Filipino stew made with oxtail, tripe, and vegetables in a peanut-based sauce.
recipes.recipe_instructions:
1. Boil the oxtail and tripe in a large pot with 8 cups of water and a pinch of salt for 2-3 hours, or until tender. Skim off any impurities that rise to the surface.

2. In a separate pan, saut√© the garlic and onion in oil until the onion is translucent.

3. Add the ground rice and annatto seeds to the pan and cook until lightly browned.

4. Add the peanut butter and a cup of the broth from the oxtail and tripe. Stir until the peanut butter is dissolved and the mixture is smooth.

5. Pour the peanut butter mixture back into the large pot with the oxtail and tripe. Add more water if necessary to achieve desired consistency.

6. Add the eggplant and string beans and cook for 5 minutes.

7. Add the bok choy and cook for an additional 3 minutes.

8. Season with salt and pepper to taste.

9. Serve hot with steamed rice and shrimp paste on the side.
